 BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA EMERGENCY EDUCATION RECONSTRUCTION PROJECT TECHNICAL ANNEX A. Background Units of Government and their Roles in Education 1. Education in former Yugoslavia was highly decentralized. Municipalities were responsible for primary education; regions were responsible for secondary education; republics were responsible for higher education. The functions of republic and regional governments were reduced further during the war, as budgets disappeared and as staff were mobilized for the war effort. The 1994 Federation Constitution creates eight regional cantons, and assigns to them responsibility for all education functions. The Federation explicitly permits the cantons to delegate education functions upward to the Federation or downward to municipalities, and requires that educational functions be delegated downward to municipalities which are predominately of an ethnic group other than the majority ethnic group in the canton. Because only two cantons are yet operational, a number of educational functions will need to be delegated to other levels of government.!' 2. In the medium term, it is desirable that careful thought be given to the educational responsibilities which are appropriate to the various levels of government, and the financial resources which need to go with them. For efficiency reasons in a country as small as Bosnia- Herzegovina (BH), such functions as curriculum development, textbook development, and quality control should be administered at the State level. But for practical reasons, political reconciliation between the two State entities -- and even between the two Federation partners -- will need to progress further before this desired integration can occur fully. Once they are fully established, the cantons may play an important role in functions such as pedagogical inspection, in-service teacher training, and introduction of new teaching methods. Day-to-day management of primary schools and most secondary schools should probably be the responsibility of municipalities, but local financial resources will need to be supplemented with resources from the entity or State level in order to maintain quality standards in a situation of sizeable local and regional disparities in income. Pre-war education system 3. Prior to the start of hostilities, Bosnia-Herzegovina had a well-developed education system, financed by public expenditures accounting for about 6 percent of GDP. Virtually all children completed the eight-year primary cycle; most also completed the four-year secondary cycle. As elsewhere in the region, most secondary education was offered in the form of narrowly specialized vocational education programs, oriented to the needs of industry. Higher education was offered through four universities, comprising 46 institutes and faculties. Higher education enrollments emphasized science and engineering. There were no fees for higher education for Yugoslav nationals; foreign students paid tuition. In primary, secondary, and higher education, students were responsible for purchasing their own textbooks. 1/ The Project is expected to help create implementation capacity at the canton level by implementing the two largest components at the regional level. Where they exist -- notably, in Tuzla and Bihac -- the cantons will perform this role. Where cantons have not yet been formally established, these components will be implemented with informal regional associations of municipalities. The institutional strengthening which is to be provided to these bodies under the Project is expected to help transform them into functional cantons.
 - 2 - Wartime Impact on the Education Systemz' 4. Physical Plant. All aspects of education have been severely disrupted by the war. Well over 50 percent of school buildings in Bosnia-Herzegovina have been seriously damaged or destroyed, or taken over for use by the army or to house people displaced by the war. In the remaining space available, students and teachers face classrooms with no glass in the windows and no heat; classes are even held in rooms missing walls and doors As schools were destroyed or unsafe, each school as an administrative entity was responsible for finding alternative space in the neighborhood for classes - often, in apartments, basements, shelters, garages, or abandoned offices. These "war schools" still exist in most front-line areas, and wherever schools were destroyed. To accommodate students displaced by destroyed schools and the influx of displaced persons, most schools function in two or three shifts of 3 1/2 hours, and offer instruction in a very abbreviated class year -- 18 weeks at most, instead of the 38 weeks called for in the curriculum. 5. Teaching Staff. The Ministry of Education, Science, Culture, and Sports of the Federation of Bosnia-Herzegovina (MOE) has tried to keep the system functioning under impossible circumstances. It is operating on a skeleton staff, and there has been no regular budget for education since the 1991-92 academic year. Teachers are working essentially without compensation in the Bosniac-majority areas, while teachers in the Croat-majority areas have received partial salaries throughout the conflict period. An undetermined number of qualified teachers have been lost through migration, mobilization into the military, and war casualties. Many teachers currently in the classroom are wartime volunteers, and lack pedagogic training. The MOE has collected data on available teachers and qualifications, revealing severe shortages of teachers in languages, math and science. 6. Textbooks and Educational Materials. The availability of textbooks and educational materials varies between the Croat-majority and Bosniac-majority areas of the Federation. Croat majority areas have been relatively well-supplied with textbooks provided by the Croatian Government, and are also relatively well-provisioned with basic educational materials provided by parents, communities and the schools themselves. In the Bosniac areas, many schools lack even the most basic educational materials needed for effective learning such as notebooks, pens and chalk. The Federation Pedagogic Institute published and distributed 56 new textbook titles in 1994 in history, culture, reading and Bosnian language with the support of various donors. Textbooks in natural sciences and math for both primary and secondary education have not been made available to schools in over four years, which represents the average life of a textbook printed in the former Yugoslavia. School libraries have also been destroyed and depleted during the war, and students in Bosniac-majority areas lack basic reading material. It is unlikely, in the short term, that the two partners in the Federation will agree to use commnon textbooks, but common usage of basic readers and educational materials should be possible. 7. Although the Federation Ministry of Education is in the process of updating its list of approved textbooks for the Bosniac-majority areas, it has not yet taken a broader, long term view of its policy for textbook production and financing, which is closely related to needed reforms in curriculum structure and content. A preliminary analysis of the current situation is that there are too many textbooks required for too many specialized subjects. There is almost certainly scope to reduce the number of books required and to improve their pedagogic content and coverage. The few textbooks that are available have been provided free of charge to schools, which lend books to students during the school year. Textbooks were provided to students free of charge in the former Yugoslavia. Given the current situation in Bosniac-majority schools and the limited ability of parents to cover costs in the short term, getting basic textbooks, readers and educational materials into classrooms, particularly in the natural sciences and math, is an urgent priority which cannot be put on hold until the longer-term policy work is completed. 8. Schools and Enrollments. Reliable data on education in the Federation of Bosnia-Herzegovina are scarce for several reasons: a) political fragmentation within the Federation and parallel structures make it difficult to cross-reference the available data; b) difficult access to certain areas hampers data collection and assessment of the current situation; and c) in some areas, the situation changes from day to day as a result of the war-related refugee movements. Thus, basic educational statistics will need to be refined in the early stages of the recovery effort. 9. It is clear, however, that access to education in Bosnia has been severely limited. Between 1990 and 1995, primary enrollments in the Federation of Bosnia-Herzegovina reportedly declined by over 50 percent -- from 542,000 to 255,000; secondary enrollments also declined by over 50 percent -- from 168,000 to 82,000; higher education enrollments declined from 35,000 to about 18,000. These figures understate the true disruption for many schools -- which have suffered frequent changes of teachers and students, changes of premises, deprivation of the most basic learning materials, and the recurring trauma of violence and its personal consequences. The most current education statistics available for the Federation, organized by level of education and by ethnic group, are presented in Appendix 6. 10. School Damages. War damage to school infrastructure is extensive. The Ministry of Energy and Industry has prepared a general assessment of total school reconstruction needs at each level of education in the Federation, net of furniture and equipment needs. The assessment shows that over 50 percent of both primary and secondary schools have sustained damage during the war and that over 30 percent of all schools have sustained significant damage (more than 15 percent needing refurbishment). Official estimates of war damages for all levels of education are presented in Appendix 7. It is also estimated that about 50 percent of schools do not have basic desks and chairs for teachers and students. B. Bank Response and Recovery Strategy for Education Emergency Reconstruction Program 11. Education governance in Bosnia-Herzogovina is currently in a state of flux, making decisions and coordination between levels -- entities, cantons, municipalities, and schools -- difficult (paragraphs I and 2). Logistical constraints to communication and political tensions add to the difficulties. However, education sector reconstruction cannot be put on hold until these issues are resolved. The Federation Ministry of Education has placed great emphasis on encouraging communications and cooperation among canton and municipality-level authorities -- for example, to develop practical mechanisms for allocating investment financing and operating funds within the country. Preparation of the proposed Project for emergency reconstruction has helped to facilitate contacts between the Federation MOE and the cantons/municipalities. The same is expected for the Republika Srpska. Implementation of the Project should be an important vehicle for continued cooperation.
 - 4 - 12. Because of the current state of flux in education governance, reconstructing the education sector will be difficult to plan, as well as to implement. The Government and donors realize that addressing all priority programs at the same time and in a well-coordinated manner is simply not possible under current constraints. Flexibility and communication on the part of the Government and donors will be key to implementing an effective investment programs in education in the near term. As part of preparations for the Brussels donor conference in December, the broad goals of a reconstruction program for education were agreed. The highest priority objectives are to make fully functional those classrooms which were damaged by the war, to restore effective teaching capacity by providing minimal supplies of textbooks, supplementary readers, and educational materials, and to support the resumption of at-least minimal salaries for teachers. The priority within the school reconstruction program is to start with efforts which would restore effective classroom teaching fastest and at the least cost. At the same time, the MOE will attempt to build its own institutional capacity to manage and coordinate the rec instruction effort and to deal with longer-term policy issues. 13. Although the Government's emphasis now is rightly on emergency reconstruction needs, government authorities and donors have identified a number of key policy issues which will necessarily have to be addressed in parallel with the provision of emergency reconstruction support. In addition to the overall governance issue mentioned above, these include the appropriateness of curriculum and content for education in Bosnia and Herzegovina, textbook production and financing, and the structure of secondary and adult education. As in other education systems of the region, there is an inherited legacy of over-specialization in secondary technical and vocational education, an excessively specialized and ideology-laden curriculum, and outdated teaching and learning methodologies. Structural reforms are needed, particularly at the secondary level, to reorient education in Bosnia to the requirements of a modern market economy and post-Communist society. The Ministries of Education of the two entities are aware of the need to introduce systemic reforms and will, for the time being, take the lead in working with external assistance in these crucial areas. Eventual implementation of initiatives concerning broad education reform will, of course, need to await a resolution of governance issues. In the meantime, emergency support is being focused on providing core textbooks and basic learning materials to teachers and students. 14. An education reconstruction program of about US$250 million is currently under consideration by the international donor community to support the above priorities. Of this total, US$189 million is for activities in the Federation; the balance represents estimated reconstruction needs in the Republika Srpska. This program is part of the three-year, US$5.1 billion reconstruction program for all sectors which the Bank and the European Community (EC) have helped to develop in a joint effort with the Government and the donor commnunity. It is expected that some of these needs will be met by a continuation of current donor assistance, the future costs of which are included in the figures in Table 1.

IBRD/IDA Assistance Strategy 16. To date, education reconstruction efforts on the part of the Government and donors have been on a relatively small scale and ad hoc in nature, reflecting the plethora of urgent needs and multiplicity of donors and the difficult environment for planning, implementing and coordinating specific investments. In this context, the Bank has decided, in consultation with the Government and key education donors, to support education reconstruction with a series of investment projects to be implemented over a three year period which can be designed to respond quickly as political tensions decrease, more hard information becomes available and governance and policy issues are resolved. This first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project is focused on mneeting emergency needs which will allow primary education in the country to operate at minimum acceptable standards. It will also provide assistance to allow the MOE to begin to address some of the key policy issues outlined above. A second and eventually a third education project will provide resources to continue reconstruction in primary education, as well as begin to rebuild secondary facilities in the context of a broader secondary reform program. The latter two

These projects will gradually shift in terms of their objectives from emergency reconstruction to longer term development priorities. Significant co-financing and parallel financing is needed for all three projects. 17. Although it is vitally important to restore teachers' salaries as soon as possible, it is not proposed to support them unless the Government develops a feasible plan for payment, and unless other sources of donor financing are identified. Initial needs for minimal teachers' salaries are estimated at US$20 million for BH in the first year. Donor financing for teacher salaries, if confirmed, would be included in the second education reconstruction project, to be implemented in parallel with the proposed Emergency Education Reconstruction Project. C. Detailed Project Description 18. The primary objective of the Project is to support Bosnia and Herzegovina's efforts to restore the delivery of primary education of acceptable quality during the 1996-97 school year. A secondary objective is to help build capacity for planning and implementation of education programs at the State, entity, canton, and municipality level. 19. To achieve these objectives under the prevailing constraints, this first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project focusses on meeting immediate educational needs in primary schooling which can, for the most part, be put in place prior to the start of the next school year in September, 1996. The Project will support actions to enable primary schools throughout the Federation to operate at minimum acceptable educational standards, and will prepare for similar actions in the Republika Srpska (RS). The Project will support the rehabilitation of a first tranche of lightly damaged primary schools throughout the Federation which have been identified by municipality and cantonal authorities as being of the highest priority for reconstruction, and the reconstruction of destroyed schools in a limited number of cases where no alternative capacity exists. It will also provide essential textbooks, supplementary reading materials, and other educational materials to most primary classrooms throughout the Federation, and will support actions to begin to strengthen the Federation's capacity to implement education programs at all levels of government. These actions will benefit a broad cross-section of communities throughout the Federation. Project resources are to be allocated to cantons throughout the Federation on the basis of population; project resources are to be allocated within cantons on the basis of local priorities for education reconstruction. 20. Although it was not possible to assess reconstruction needs and capacity in the Republika Srpska during the period when the proposed Project was prepared and appraised, it is expected that the RS will participate in the next stage of reconstruction for the education sector in Bosnia and Herzegovina. In order to ensure that the RS is ready to participate in donor-financed projects at the State level and to help make up for time lost due to the embargo, financing is provided under this Project to enable authorities in the RS to assess education reconstruction needs, and to prepare and pilot education reconstruction actions which would be supported under subsequent donor-financed education reconstruction projects. 21. This component will provide financing for (i) the refurbishment of about 70 large primary schools (estimated cost, US$18.0 million); (ii) the construction of about three replacement primary schools (estimated cost, US$3.0 million); (iii) the provision of furniture for classrooms in these schools (estimated cost, US$2.0 million); and (iv) design and management assistance (estimated cost, US$2.3 million). The reconstruction represents about 18 percent of the Federation's estimated primary school reconstruction needs. A description of the process and criteria used to select schools to benefit from reconstruction and refurnishing is provided below. Construction will be carried out by local construction contractors to be selected on a competitive basis. Architectural designs and specifications will be developed by the MOE's implementation management agent, the International Management Group (IMG) (see Section D), using local contractors; this work will be financed on a grant basis by the EU. 23. Selection of Primary Schools for Refurbishment and Replacement. Schools have been selected and agreed with the Bank for refurbishment and reconstruction under the Project under the following procedure. (A list of the specific schools selected for rehabilitation and reconstruction under the Project is available upon request.) The initial selection was carried out on the basis of the Government's strategy to focus initial reconstruction support for education on schools which can be rapidly rehabilitated, thereby restoring education facilitates to the greatest possible number of students for the 1996-97 school year. As the agency responsible for overseeing the school reconstruction process at the Federation level, the MOE took the lead in defining criteria for selecting schools and reaching agreement on the criteria with the Bank, as well as for working with canton-level education ministries and other education authorities (in the cases where canton-level ministries are not yet formed) to apply the criteria to the needs of the various municipalities. During February 1996, the MOE requested canton-level authorities to identify the primary schools in their areas which: (i) had sustained light to medium war-related damage or deterioration; (ii) were not benefiting from or expected to benefit from other donor financing; and (iii) could be refurbished to allow students to attend classes during the 1996-97 school year. It also asked for supplementary information which would allow it to further prioritize schools to benefit from financing in this first Project. This information included student and teacher numbers (both trained and untrained teachers), numbers of classrooms (both in use and currently not usable), and a brief description of rehabilitation work to be carried out. In addition, canton authorities were asked to propose the replacement of fully destroyed or otherwise unusable schools only if these schools could be justified on the basis of: (i) the number of students without access to any school facility; and (ii) evidence that the population of the catchment area is stable, such as comparisons with the former population of the area and the availability of permanent housing. 24. Authorities were asked to request school furniture only in cases where basic furniture such as blackboards, desks and chairs for students and teachers, small shelves and book cupboards did not exist for an existing classroom or one to be refurbished or constructed under the program. Replacement of old or partially damaged furniture will not be included in this first phase. 25. Once this information was received from individual cantons, the MOE used the agreed criteria and supplementary information to bring funding proposals in line with funds expected to be available under the first-year school rehabilitation program (about US$20 million). Schools not selected for this first phase of reconstruction would be eligible for financing in second and third phase lending operations. Balance between funds made available to the various cantons was also sought on a per-capita basis. The MOE, in cooperation with its implementation agent, IMG (see implementation arrangements in Section D), will verify all information provided by the canton level prior to beginning competitive selection of construction contractors and furniture

Refurbishment costs have been estimated by the MOE and canton authorities to be about US$400 per square meter on average and the average cost for new construction of replacement schools is estimated to be US$800 per square meter. These costs are high, reflecting both elevated materials pricing during the war, and a lack of knowledge of post-war construction costs. It is expected that IMG's participation in the verification process and the use of competitive selection will lead to a reduction in the actual square-meter costs. Canton authorities would be invited to reallocate any cost savings within their cantons to undertake work on priority schools that were not selected from their original requests due to lack of funds, thereby providing an incentive for economy in square-meter costs. The cost of school furniture is estimated to be US$4,000 per classroom, based on a classroom size of 32 per class. This estimate is based on recent experience with furniture manufacturing in Bosnia. Books and Educational Materials 27. This component (estimated cost US$6.1 million) will finance the printing of textbooks and the purchase and printing of supplementary readers for primary and secondary education, as well as basic educational materials packages for primary schools. This material is expected to be delivered to schools for the 1996-97 school year. Titles selected for production and delivery under the Project are principally in science, math, and literature; textbooks and readers covering controversial subject matter -- particularly, in areas such as history and geography -- are not provided under the Project. The average unit cost for textbooks is estimated to be US$4 and the average unit cost for readers is estimated to be US$3. Educational materials are estimated to cost US$130 per classroom package. 28. The Federation MOE is in the process of completely updating its list of approved textbooks. Beginning in 1993, it organized two competitions in which authors were invited to submit manuscripts against a list of standard subjects for both primary and secondary education. The manuscripts were evaluated and selected by committees established by the Federation MOE. The first selection of 56 textbooks, which cover Bosnian history, language and culture, were printed in Slovenia using donor financing and distributed to schools in Bosniac-majority areas in 1994. A second list of 72 textbooks have been submitted to donors for financing covering a broader range of subjects. These books have not been accepted for use in Croat majority areas where textbooks are imported from Croatia. Educational authorities in Sarajevo and Mostar are cooperating to investigate the use of a limited number of common textbooks for use throughout the Federation, which could be financed in a second phase. For this Project, eight supplementary reader titles, but no text titles were selected in common by educational authorities for both Federation partners. Priority in selection was given to primary-level textbooks and science and math books for general secondary education. More specialized secondary texts were excluded, pending a review of the structure and content of secondary education in Bosnia. 29. A total of 84 textbook titles have been selected and agreed with the Bank for printing under the Project. (A list of these textbook titles is available upon request.) These manuscripts are currently being readied for printing by the Federation MOE under co-financing provided by the Government of the Netherlands. The total cost of textbook production under the Project is estimated at US$2.8 million. Textbooks will be printed by private printing houses selected under international shopping procedures; most, but not all printers invited to submit bids will be local. All books to be printed with proceeds from this Project will be included in the Federal MOE's approved list of textbooks. Print runs are estimated to be approximately 35,000 for a general primary text, and 6,000 for a general secondary text.

The capacity of these agencies to handle distribution was proven in that they successfully distributed the 56 national subject textbooks printed in 1995 using their own resources. As an alternative, the Bank has agreed that delivery of books to canton-level warehouses can be included in the printing contracts, or procured locally on a competitive basis. Reconstruction of primary schools throughout the Federation including civil works contracting, the preparation of architectural designs and specifications and the supervision of works. 2. doc.abstracts: The primary objective of the Emergency Education Reconstruction Project is to support Bosnia and Herzegovina's efforts to restore the delivery of primary education of acceptable quality during the 1996-97 school year. A second objective is to help build capacity for planning and implementation of education programs at the state, entity, canton, and municipality level. To achieve these objectives under the prevailing constraints, the project focuses on meeting immediate educational needs in primary schooling which can, for the most part, be put in place prior to the start of the next school year in September, 1996. The components of the project are the following: 1) primary school reconstruction; 2) books and educational materials; 3) project implementation and capacity building; and 4) project preparation and pilot implementation in the Republica Srpska. They include civil works, provision of furniture and equipment and technical assistance and training.
